ygData.subject: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007
ygData.msgSnippet: I just got around to viewing the video of the keynote discussion from GECCO 2007, and it was nice to see that Ken had asked a question of the panel. Here s the

Subject: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=183620858; y=_1ScLjK3FqupyWTi_ecAVxH350Xtbhp4HR9NO65tKE-MbRE

I just got around to viewing the video of the keynote discussion from
GECCO 2007, and it was nice to see that Ken had asked a question of
the panel. Here's the link to the download:

http://www.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/p.bentley/evodebate.html

Ken asked: "How is it possible for 30,000 human genes to encode the
connectivity of a 100 trillion-connection brain? And how is it
possible for evolution to search a space of such astronomical
complexity to discover such a structure?"

I was wondering what Ken thought of the answers to the question. I
wasn't much impressed with them. Admittedly it's a difficult question,
and the panel admitted that nobody really knows. Jones seemed to say
that there might be a lot more information in DNA than we're giving it
credit for, although he brought up Mandelbrot sets as examples of
complicated patterns that can arise from very simple rules.

Wolpert didn't have much to say, though he seemed to say the answer
may lie in combinatorics. And Dawkins used the computer code analogy,
talking about the reuse of particular sections of code, which probably
came closest to providing a decent answer, but none of them seemed
very satisfactory to me.

--Derek
